awd_titl_txt: Women in Cognitive Science: Mentoring, Negotiation, and Obtaining Funding
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of Women in Cognitive Science is to improve the visibility of women scientists by fostering an environment that welcomes and nurtures young women scholars, to contribute to the professional development of scholars throughout their career, and to facilitate creation of a network that will provide contacts and connections to other women in science. Several workshops are designed for women in cognitive science, especially women in the early stages of their academic career. The workshops focus on negotiation techniques to create opportunities and optimize mechanisms to sustain research visibility and productivity. A second focus is on grant application writing for predoctoral, postdoctoral, and early career scientists. Workshops will take place at meetings of the Psychonomic Society, the Cognitive Science Society, and  the Association for Psychological Sciences. The workshops will take the form of a public forum with invited speaker-panelists to initiate discussion about best practices for the professional advancement of women in cognitive science at the individual and institutional level. By partnering with these established societies, the workshops will maximize the outreach potential to a group that continues to be underrepresented in senior academic positions in the cognitive sciences.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the activities of Women in Cognitive Science (WiCS). WiCS was founded with the goal to improve the visibility of women scientists by fostering an environment that welcomes and nurtures junior women scholars who wish to contribute to the fields within Psychology and Cognitive Science that traditionally attract fewer women than men. These include cognitive science, experimental psychology, and cognitive neuroscience. WiCS also aims to contribute to the professional development of scholars throughout their career, to facilitate the creation of a network that will provide contacts and connections to other women in science, and to improve the visibility of women by ensuring their presence on policymaking committees and editorial boards. Broadly, WiCS seeks to remedy gender stereotypes in both women and men to come to a fair and accurate evaluation of women's and men's ability and professional achievements as pertains to advancement.

To this end, this award included six major activities. First, panel discussions and workshops were conducted at several major conferences annually. Second, WiCS gave mentorship and travel/networking awards. An overarching goal of both award programs is to generate external recognition (from the WiCS award) to increase the visibility of women within their home institution, and within their academic discipline. Acknowledging the well-documented importance of productive mentorship, WiCS has initiated Mentorship Awards to recognize senior scientists who have an exemplary track record of supporting and mentoring female scientists. WiCS travel awards were given to junior female scholars who would like to attend a conference to network with one or two more senior scientists. The applications included a networking plan and an agreement by the targeted senior scientist(s) to meet with the individual. This is a valuable mechanism by which junior women scientists can begin to network with the ultimate goal of increasing research productivity by entering into a collaboration with a more senior scholar. In one year, we also offered international awards that sent junior female scientists to international sites to network with international collaborators. Third, we partnered with a related organization (Women of Math Psych) to offer travel awards to their members, and to fund speakers at their events for the same purposes as outlned above. Fourth, WiCS continued the development of programmatic initiatives with other professional organizations with which we have had less contact (e.g., Mathematical Psychology, American Psychological Association). Fifth, we have gained additional information about our members so that we have better insight into the types of initiatives that will serve them best in the future. Sixth, during this award period, we began to offer "speed-mentoring" sessions at our events, which provide trainees (graduate students, postdocs, and Assistant Professors) with one-on-one mentoring with a more senior faculty member in their field.
